conclusion: State A: pₐ = 3 × 10⁵ Pa, Vₐ = 1 × 10⁻³ m³, Tₐ = 27 °C = 300 K
State B: pᵦ = 1 × 10⁵ Pa, Vᵦ = 1 × 10⁻³ m³ (same volume as A; the graph shows a vertical drop)
For an ideal gas the state equation is p V = n R T (n is the same for all states of the given mass of gas).
Taking the ratio of the equations for states B and A: (pᵦ Vᵦ)/(pₐ Vₐ) = Tᵦ/Tₐ
Because Vᵦ = Vₐ, the volumes cancel: Tᵦ = Tₐ (pᵦ/pₐ)
Convert back to Celsius: Tᵦ = 100 K – 273 ≈ –173 °C
Answer: The temperature at state B is about –1.7 × 10² °C (≈ 100 K).
